subChapterTitle: Objective
content: This ESRS sets out the disclosure requirements that apply to all undertakings regardless of their sector of activity (i.e., sector agnostic) and apply across sustainability topics (i.e., crosscutting). This ESRS covers the reporting areas defined in ESRS 1 General requirements section 1.2 Cross-Cutting Standards and reporting areas.
summary: This ESRS outlines universal disclosure requirements for all businesses, regardless of sector, covering various sustainability topics and reporting areas.

subChapterTitle: Objective
content: In the preparation of disclosures under this Standard, the undertaking shall apply the Disclosure Requirements (including their datapoints) set in topical ESRS, as listed in Appendix C of this Standard Disclosure/Application Requirements in topical ESRS that are applicable jointly with ESRS 2 General Disclosures. The undertaking shall apply the requirements listed in Appendix C:\n (a) in all instances for the requirements in topical standards related to Disclosure Requirement IRO-1 Description of the processes to identify and assess material impacts, risks and opportunities; and\n (b) for all other requirements listed in appendix C, only if the sustainability topic is material based on the undertaking's materiality assessment (see ESRS 1 chapter 3 Double materiality as the basis for sustainability disclosures).
summary: The undertaking must follow the Disclosure Requirements in topical ESRS, applying them in all instances for IRO-1 Description and only if the topic is material based on the undertaking's assessment for other requirements.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement BP-1 - General basis for preparation of the sustainability statement
content: The undertaking shall disclose the general basis for preparation of its sustainability statement
summary: The company will reveal the basic method used to create its sustainability report.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement BP-1 - General basis for preparation of the sustainability statement
content: The objective of this Disclosure Requirement is to provide an understanding of how the undertaking prepares its sustainability statement, including the scope of consolidation, the upstream and downstream value chain information and, where relevant, whether the undertaking has used any of the options for omitting information referred to in points d) and e) in the following paragraph.
summary: This Disclosure Requirement aims to explain how a company prepares its sustainability statement, including consolidation scope, value chain information, and any omitted information.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement BP-1 - General basis for preparation of the sustainability statement
summary: The undertaking must disclose information about its sustainability statement, including its basis, scope, coverage of the value chain, any omitted information, and use of any exemptions from disclosure.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement BP-1 - General basis for preparation of the sustainability statement
content:
When describing to what extent the sustainability statement covers the undertaking's upstream and downstream value chain (see ESRS 1 section 5.1 Reporting undertaking and value chain), the undertaking may distinguish between:
 (a) the extent to which its materiality assessment of impacts, risks and opportunities extends to its upstream and/or downstream value chain;
 (b) the extent to which its policies, actions and targets extend to its value chain; and
 (c) the extent to which it includes upstream and/or downstream value chain data when disclosing on metrics.
summary: The sustainability statement discusses the extent of the undertaking's impact assessment, policies, actions, targets, and data disclosure in its upstream and downstream value chain.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement BP-2 - Disclosures in relation to specific circumstances
content: The undertaking shall provide disclosures in relation to specific circumstances.
summary: The project will offer information about particular situations.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement BP-2 - Disclosures in relation to specific circumstances
content: The objective of this Disclosure Requirement is to provide an understanding of the effect of these specific circumstances on the preparation of the sustainability statement.
summary: This Disclosure Requirement aims to explain how specific circumstances impact the creation of the sustainability statement.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement BP-2 - Disclosures in relation to specific circumstances
content: The undertaking may report this information alongside the disclosures to which they refer
summary: The project may include this information with the related disclosures.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement BP-2 - Disclosures in relation to specific circumstances
content: When the undertaking has deviated from the medium- or long-term time horizons defined by ESRS 1 section 6.4 Definition of short-, medium- and long-term for reporting purposes, it shall describe:\n (a) its definitions of medium- or long-term time horizons; and (b) the reasons for applying those definitions.
summary: If a project strays from the set timeframes, it must explain its new definitions of medium or long-term periods and why they were used.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement BP-2 - Disclosures in relation to specific circumstances
summary: When using indirect sources for value chain data, the undertaking must identify the metrics, explain the preparation basis, describe the accuracy level, and if relevant, outline future plans to enhance accuracy.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement BP-2 - Disclosures in relation to specific circumstances
content:
In accordance with ESRS 1 section 7.2 Sources of estimation and outcome uncertainty, the undertaking shall:
 (a) identify the quantitative metrics and monetary amounts it has disclosed that are subject to a high level of measurement uncertainty;
 (b) in relation to each quantitative metric and monetary amount identified:
 (bi) disclose information about the sources of measurement uncertainty (for example, the dependence of the amount on the outcome of a future event, on a measurement technique or on the availability and quality of data from the entity's upstream and/or downstream value chain); and
 (bii) disclose the assumptions, approximations and judgements the entity has made in measuring it.
summary: The undertaking must identify and disclose information about the quantitative metrics and monetary amounts with high measurement uncertainty, including their sources and the assumptions made in measuring them.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement BP-2 - Disclosures in relation to specific circumstances
content: When disclosing forward-looking information, the undertaking may indicate that it considers such information to be uncertain.
summary: The company may express uncertainty about its future predictions.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement BP-2 - Disclosures in relation to specific circumstances
content:
When changes in the preparation and presentation of sustainability information occur compared to the previous reporting period(s), (see ESRS 1 section 7.4 Changes in preparation or presentation in sustainability information), the undertaking shall:
 (a) explain the changes and the reasons for them, including why the replaced metric provides more useful information;
 (b) disclose revised comparative figures, unless it is impracticable to do so. When it is impracticable to adjust comparative information for one or more prior periods, the undertaking shall disclose that fact; and
 (c) disclose the difference between the figure disclosed in the preceding period and the revised comparative figure.
summary: When sustainability information preparation or presentation changes, the entity must explain the changes, provide revised figures, and disclose the difference between the old and new figures.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement BP-2 - Disclosures in relation to specific circumstances
content:
When the undertaking identifies material prior period errors (see ESRS 1 section 7.5 Reporting errors in prior periods), it shall disclose:
 (a) the nature of the prior period material error;
 (b) to the extent practicable, the correction for each prior period included in the sustainability statement; and
 (c) if correction of the error is not practicable, the circumstances that led to the existence of that condition.
summary: When a project finds significant errors from previous periods, it must disclose the error's nature, the correction for each past period in the sustainability statement, and the reasons if the error can't be corrected.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement BP-2 - Disclosures in relation to specific circumstances
content: When the undertaking includes in its sustainability statement information stemming from other legislation which requires the undertaking to disclose sustainability information or from generally accepted sustainability reporting standards and frameworks (see ESRS 1 section 8.2 Content and structure of the sustainability statement), in addition to the information prescribed by ESRS, it shall disclose this fact. In case of partial application of other reporting standards or frameworks, the undertaking shall provide a precise reference to the paragraphs of the standard or framework applied.
summary: The undertaking must disclose if it includes additional sustainability information from other laws or standards in its sustainability statement, and provide specific references if only parts of other standards are used.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement BP-2 - Disclosures in relation to specific circumstances
content: When the undertaking incorporates information by reference (see ESRS 1 section 9.1 Incorporation by reference), it shall disclose a list of the disclosure requirements of ESRS, or the specific datapoints mandated by a Disclosure Requirement, that have been incorporated by reference.
summary: The undertaking must disclose a list of ESRS disclosure requirements or specific datapoints that have been incorporated by reference.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement BP-2 - Disclosures in relation to specific circumstances
summary: If a business with less than 750 employees omits certain information, it must still disclose if sustainability topics have been deemed material, describe how these topics affect their business model and strategy, list any related targets, describe their policies and actions regarding these matters, and disclose relevant metrics.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement BP-2 - Disclosures in relation to specific circumstances
content: The undertaking may disclose whether it relies on any European standards approved by the European Standardisation System (ISO/IEC or CEN/CENELEC standards), as well as the extent to which data and processes that are used for sustainability reporting purposes have been verified by an external assurance provider and found to conform to the corresponding ISO/IEC or CEN/CENELEC standard.
summary: The task involves revealing reliance on European standards and the verification of sustainability reporting data and processes by an external provider.

subChapterTitle: 2. Governance
content: The objective of this chapter is to set disclosure requirements that enable an understanding of the governance processes, controls and procedures put in place to monitor, manage and oversee sustainability matters.
summary: This chapter aims to establish rules for disclosing how sustainability issues are monitored, managed, and overseen.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement GOV-1 - The role of the administrative, management and supervisory bodies
content: The undertaking shall disclose the composition of the administrative, management and supervisory bodies, their roles and responsibilities and access to expertise and skills with regard to sustainability matters.
summary: The company will reveal the structure of its management bodies, their duties, and their knowledge on sustainability issues.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement GOV-1 - The role of the administrative, management and supervisory bodies
content:
The objective of this Disclosure Requirement is to provide an understanding of:
 (a) the composition and diversity of the administrative, management and supervisory bodies;
 (b) the roles and responsibilities of the administrative, management and supervisory bodies in exercising oversight of the process to manage material impacts, risks and opportunities, including management's role in these processes; and
 (c) the expertise and skills of its administrative, management and supervisory bodies on sustainability matters or access to such expertise and skills.
summary: This Disclosure Requirement aims to clarify the structure, roles, responsibilities, and sustainability expertise of the administrative, management and supervisory bodies.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement GOV-1 - The role of the administrative, management and supervisory bodies
summary: The company must disclose information about the number, diversity, representation, experience, and independence of its administrative, management, and supervisory bodies' members.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement GOV-1 - The role of the administrative, management and supervisory bodies
summary: The company must disclose information about the identities, roles, and responsibilities of its administrative, management, and supervisory bodies, including their involvement in overseeing impacts, risks, and opportunities, and how they monitor progress towards set targets.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement GOV-1 - The role of the administrative, management and supervisory bodies
content: The disclosure shall include a description of how the administrative, management and supervisory bodies determine whether appropriate skills and expertise are available or will be developed to oversee sustainability matters, including:\n (a) the sustainability-related expertise that the bodies, as a whole, either directly possess or can leverage, for example through access to experts or training; and\n (b) how those skills and expertise relate to the undertaking's material impacts, risks and opportunities
summary: The disclosure will detail how the organization's leadership assesses and ensures the availability or development of skills and expertise for overseeing sustainability matters.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement GOV-1 - The role of the administrative, management and supervisory bodies
summary: The text describes how a company's administrative, management, and supervisory bodies oversee and manage sustainability matters, including strategy changes, risk assessment, policy creation, and sustainability reporting.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement GOV-1 - The role of the administrative, management and supervisory bodies
content: In describing the undertaking's organisation of governance regarding sustainability matters, a description of complex governance structure may be complemented by their presentation in the form of a diagram.
summary: The project's sustainability governance can be explained through a detailed description and a diagram.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement GOV-1 - The role of the administrative, management and supervisory bodies
content: The description of the level of expertise or access to expertise of the administrative, management and supervisory bodies may be substantiated by illustrating the composition of the bodies, including members on whom these bodies rely for expertise to oversee sustainability matters, and how they leverage that expertise as a body. In the description, the undertaking shall consider how the expertise and skills are relevant to the undertaking's material impacts, risks and opportunities and whether the bodies and/or its members have access to other sources of expertise, such as specific experts and training and other educational initiatives to update and develop sustainability-related expertise within these bodies.
summary: The text discusses how a company's administrative, management, and supervisory bodies utilize their expertise and access to other experts to manage sustainability matters, considering their impacts, risks, and opportunities.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement GOV-2 - Information provided to and sustainability matters addressed by the undertaking's administrative, management and supervisory bodies
content: The undertaking shall disclose how the administrative, management and supervisory bodies are informed about sustainability matters and how these matters were addressed during the reporting period.
summary: The project will reveal how its leaders are informed about sustainability issues and how these were handled during the reported period.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement GOV-2 - Information provided to and sustainability matters addressed by the undertaking's administrative, management and supervisory bodies
content: The objective of this Disclosure Requirement is to provide an understanding of how administrative, management and supervisory bodies are informed about sustainability matters, as well as what information and matters they addressed during the reporting period. This in turn allows an understanding of whether the members of these bodies were adequately informed and whether they were able to fulfil their roles.
summary: This Disclosure Requirement aims to clarify how leadership bodies are informed about sustainability issues and if they were able to perform their roles effectively.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement GOV-2 - Information provided to and sustainability matters addressed by the undertaking's administrative, management and supervisory bodies
content:
The undertaking shall disclose the following information:
 (a) whether, by whom and how frequently the administrative, management and supervisory bodies, including their relevant committees, are informed about material impacts, risks and opportunities (see Disclosure Requirement IRO-1 - Description of the processes to identify and assess material impacts, risks and opportunities of this Standard), the implementation of due diligence, and the results and effectiveness of policies, actions, metrics and targets adopted to address them;
 (b) how the administrative, management and supervisory bodies consider impacts, risks and opportunities when overseeing the undertaking's strategy, its decisions on major transactions, and its risk management process, including whether they have considered trade-offs associated with those impacts, risks and opportunities; and
 (c) a list of the material impacts, risks and opportunities addressed by the administrative, management and supervisory bodies, or their relevant committees during the reporting period.
summary: The company must disclose how its management is informed about significant impacts, risks, and opportunities, how these factors influence strategic decisions, and a list of these elements addressed during the reporting period.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement GOV-2 - Information provided to and sustainability matters addressed by the undertaking's administrative, management and supervisory bodies
content: Depending on the undertaking's structure, the administrative, management and supervisory bodies may focus on overarching targets, while management focuses on the more detailed targets. In this case, the undertaking may disclose how the governance bodies ensure that an appropriate mechanism for performance monitoring is in place.
summary: The governance bodies of a project focus on broad goals and ensure proper performance monitoring, while management handles detailed targets.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement GOV-3 - Integration of sustainability-related performance in incentive schemes
content: The undertaking shall disclose information about the integration of its sustainabilityrelated performance in incentive schemes.
summary: The company will share details on how its sustainability efforts are incorporated into incentive programs.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement GOV-3 - Integration of sustainability-related performance in incentive schemes
content: The objective of this Disclosure Requirement is to provide an understanding of whether incentive schemes are offered to members of the administrative, management and supervisory bodies that are linked to sustainability matters.
summary: This Disclosure Requirement aims to clarify if sustainability-related incentives are provided to administrative, management, and supervisory staff.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement GOV-3 - Integration of sustainability-related performance in incentive schemes
summary: The company must disclose information about its sustainability-related incentive schemes and remuneration policies for its administrative, management, and supervisory bodies, including their key characteristics, performance metrics, proportion of variable remuneration, and approval levels.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement GOV-3 - Integration of sustainability-related performance in incentive schemes
content: For listed undertakings, this Disclosure Requirement should be consistent with the remuneration report prescribed in articles 9a and 9b of Directive 2007/36/EC on the exercise of certain rights of shareholders in listed companies. Subject to the provisions of ESRS 1, paragraphs 119, 120 and 122, a listed undertaking may make a reference to its remuneration report.
summary: The Disclosure Requirement for listed companies should align with the remuneration report outlined in Directive 2007/36/EC, and they can refer to their remuneration report as per ESRS 1, paragraphs 119, 120, and 122.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement GOV-4 - Statement on due diligence
content: The undertaking shall disclose a mapping of the information provided in its sustainability statement about the due diligence process.
summary: The company will reveal a guide of the data in its sustainability report regarding the due diligence process.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement GOV-4 - Statement on due diligence
content: The objective of this Disclosure Requirement is to facilitate an understanding of the undertaking's due diligence process with regard to sustainability matters.
summary: This Disclosure Requirement aims to clarify the company's process for handling sustainability issues.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement GOV-4 - Statement on due diligence
content: The main aspects and steps of due diligence referred to under ESRS 1 chapter 4 Due diligence are related to a number of cross-cutting and topical Disclosure Requirements under the ESRS. The undertaking shall provide a mapping that explains how and where its application of the main aspects and steps of the due diligence process are reflected in its sustainability statement, to allow a depiction of the actual practices of the undertaking with regard to due diligence3 .
summary: The ESRS 1 chapter 4 requires companies to map out how their due diligence process is reflected in their sustainability statement.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement GOV-4 - Statement on due diligence
content: This disclosure requirement does not mandate any specific behavioural requirements with regard to due diligence actions and does not extend or modify the role of administrative, management and supervisory bodies as mandated by other legislation or regulation.
summary: This disclosure rule doesn't dictate due diligence actions or change the roles of administrative and supervisory bodies as per other laws.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement GOV-4 - Statement on due diligence
content: The mapping required by paragraph 30 may be presented in the form of a table, crossreferencing the core elements of due diligence, for impacts on people and the environment, to the relevant disclosures in the undertaking's sustainability statement, as set out below.
summary: Paragraph 30 requires a table mapping due diligence elements to sustainability statement disclosures for impacts on people and the environment.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement GOV-4 - Statement on due diligence
content: The undertaking may include additional columns to the table below to clearly identify those disclosures that relate to impacts on people and/or the environment given that, in some cases, more than one disclosure may provide information about the same due diligence step.
summary: The project might add more columns to the table to better highlight disclosures related to human and environmental impacts, as some disclosures may pertain to the same due diligence step.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement GOV-4 - Statement on due diligence
content:
The main references in the international instruments of the UN Guiding Principles on Business and Human Rights and the OECD Guidelines for Multinational Enterprises to the core elements of the due diligence process are listed in ESRS 1 chapter 4.
 (a) Embedding due diligence in governance, strategy and business model
 (b) Engaging with affected stakeholders in all key steps of the due diligence
 (c) Identifying and assessing adverse impacts
 (d) Taking actions to address those adverse impacts
 (e) Tracking the effectiveness of these efforts and communicating
summary: ESRS 1 chapter 4 lists the core elements of the due diligence process in business and human rights as per UN and OECD guidelines, including embedding due diligence, stakeholder engagement, impact assessment, action on impacts, and tracking and communication.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement GOV-5 - Risk management and internal controls over sustainability reporting
content: The undertaking shall disclose the main features of its risk management and internal control system in relation to the sustainability reporting process.
summary: The company will reveal the key aspects of its risk management and internal control system for the sustainability reporting process.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement GOV-5 - Risk management and internal controls over sustainability reporting
content: The objective of this Disclosure Requirement is to provide an understanding of the undertaking's risk management and internal control processes in relation to sustainability reporting.
summary: This Disclosure Requirement aims to clarify the company's risk management and internal control processes for sustainability reporting.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement GOV-5 - Risk management and internal controls over sustainability reporting
summary: The undertaking will disclose information about its risk management, internal control processes, risk assessment approach, main risks and their mitigation strategies, integration of risk assessment findings into internal functions, and periodic reporting to administrative bodies in relation to sustainability reporting.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement GOV-5 - Risk management and internal controls over sustainability reporting
content: This Disclosure Requirement focuses solely on the internal control processes over the sustainability reporting process. The undertaking may consider risks such as the completeness and integrity of the data, the accuracy of estimation results, the availability of upstream and/or downstream value chain data, and the timing of the availability of the information.
summary: This disclosure requirement is about managing risks in the sustainability reporting process, including data completeness, accuracy, availability, and timing.

subChapterTitle: 3. Strategy
content:
This chapter sets disclosure requirements that enable an understanding of:
 (a) the elements of the undertaking's strategy that relate to or affect sustainability matters, its business model and its value chain;
 (b) how the interests and views of the undertaking's stakeholders are taken into account by the undertaking's strategy and business model; and
 (c) the outcome of the undertaking's assessment of material impacts, risks and opportunities, including how they inform its strategy and business model.
summary: The chapter outlines disclosure requirements for a company's sustainability strategy, stakeholder involvement, and assessment of impacts, risks, and opportunities.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement SBM-1 - Strategy, business model and value chain
content: The undertaking shall disclose the elements of its strategy that relate to or impact sustainability matters, its business model and its value chain.
summary: The business will reveal its sustainability-related strategies, business model, and value chain.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement SBM-1 - Strategy, business model and value chain
content: The objective of this Disclosure Requirement is to describe the key elements of the undertaking's general strategy that relate to or affect sustainability matters, and the key elements of the undertaking's business model and value chain, in order to provide an understanding of its exposure to impacts, risks and opportunities and where they originate.
summary: This Disclosure Requirement aims to outline the company's sustainability-related strategies, business model, and value chain to understand its exposure to impacts, risks, and opportunities.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement SBM-1 - Strategy, business model and value chain
summary: The company must disclose information about its sustainability strategy, including details about its products, services, markets, customer groups, employee headcount, revenue breakdown, involvement in certain sectors like fossil fuels and controversial weapons, sustainability goals, and how its current operations align with these goals.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement SBM-1 - Strategy, business model and value chain
content: If the undertaking is based in an EU Member State that allows for an exemption from the disclosure of the information referred to in Article 18, paragraph 1, sub-point (a) of Directive 2013/34/EU8 , and if the undertaking has made use of that exemption, it may omit the breakdown of revenue by significant ESRS sector required by paragraph 40(b). In this case the undertaking shall nevertheless disclose the list of ESRS sectors that are significant for the undertaking.
summary: If a business in the EU uses a certain exemption, it can skip detailing its revenue by significant ESRS sector but must still list the significant ESRS sectors.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement SBM-1 - Strategy, business model and value chain
content:
The undertaking shall disclose a description of its business model and value chain, including:
 (a) its inputs and its approach to gathering, developing and securing those inputs;
 (b) its outputs and outcomes in terms of current and expected benefits for customers, investors and other stakeholders; and
 (c) the main features of its upstream and downstream value chain and the undertaking's position in its value chain, including a description of the main business actors (such as key suppliers, customers, distribution channels and end-users) and their relationship to the undertaking. When the undertaking has multiple value chains, the disclosure shall cover the key value chains.
summary: The business must provide a detailed description of its business model and value chain, including its inputs, outputs, position in the value chain, and relationships with key business actors.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement SBM-1 - Strategy, business model and value chain
content: To provide the information on sectors required by paragraph 40, the undertaking shall map its significant activities in accordance with ESRS sectors. If a code for a sub-sector does not exist, the caption “others” shall be used.
summary: The undertaking must categorize its significant activities according to ESRS sectors for the information needed in paragraph 40, using "others" if a sub-sector code is unavailable.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement SBM-1 - Strategy, business model and value chain
content: For the purposes of the disclosures required in paragraph 40, a group of products and/or services offered, a group of markets and/or customer groups served, or an ESRS sector, is significant for the undertaking if it meets one or both of the following criteria:\n (a) it accounts for more than 10 per cent of the undertaking's revenue;\n (b) it is connected with material actual impacts or material potential negative impacts of the undertaking.
summary: A product, market, customer group, or ESRS sector is significant if it contributes over 10% of the company's revenue or is linked with substantial actual or potential negative impacts.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement SBM-1 - Strategy, business model and value chain
summary: The undertaking should consider its key activities, business relationships, cost structure, revenue, and potential risks in its sector when preparing disclosures about its business model and value chain.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement SBM-1 - Strategy, business model and value chain
content: Contextual information may be particularly relevant for users of the undertaking's sustainability statement, to understand to what extent the disclosures include upstream and/or downstream value chain information. The description of the main features of the upstream and/or downstream value chain and where applicable the identification of key value chains should support an understanding of how the undertaking applies the requirements of ESRS 1 chapter 5 and the materiality assessment performed by the undertaking in line with ESRS 1 chapter 3. The description may provide a high-level overview of the key features of upstream and/or downstream value chain entities indicating their relative contribution to the undertaking's performance and position and explaining how they contribute to the value creation of the undertaking.
summary: The text discusses the importance of providing contextual information about an undertaking's sustainability statement, specifically about its upstream and downstream value chain, to help users understand how it meets ESRS requirements and contributes to the undertaking's performance and value creation.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement SBM-2 - Interests and views of stakeholders
content: The undertaking shall disclose how the interests and views of its stakeholders are taken into account by the undertaking's strategy and business model.
summary: The company will reveal how it considers stakeholders' interests and views in its strategy and business model.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement SBM-2 - Interests and views of stakeholders
content: The objective of this Disclosure Requirement is to provide an understanding of how stakeholders' interests and views inform the undertaking's strategy and business model.
summary: This Disclosure Requirement aims to explain how stakeholders' perspectives influence the company's strategy and business model.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement SBM-2 - Interests and views of stakeholders
summary: The text outlines the company's stakeholder engagement process, understanding of stakeholders' interests, potential strategy changes based on stakeholders' views, and how these views are communicated to the company's management.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement SBM-2 - Interests and views of stakeholders
content: The views and interests of stakeholders that are expressed as part of the undertaking's engagement with stakeholders through its due diligence process may be relevant to one or more aspects of its strategy or business model. As such, they may affect the undertaking's decisions regarding the future direction of the strategy or business model.
summary: Stakeholders' views and interests, expressed during due diligence, can influence the company's strategic and business model decisions.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement SBM-3 - Material impacts, risks and opportunities and their interaction with strategy and business model
content: The undertaking shall disclose its material impacts, risks and opportunities and how they interact with its strategy and business model.
summary: The business will reveal its significant effects, risks, and opportunities and their relation to its strategy and business model.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement SBM-3 - Material impacts, risks and opportunities and their interaction with strategy and business model
content: The objective of this Disclosure Requirement is to provide an understanding of the material impacts, risks and opportunities as they result from the undertaking's materiality assessment and how they originate from and trigger adaptation of the undertaking's strategy and business model including its resources allocation. The information to be disclosed about the management of the undertaking's material impacts, risks and opportunities is prescribed in topical ESRS and in sector-specific standards, which shall be applied in conjunction with the Minimum Disclosure Requirements on policies, actions and targets established in this Standard.
summary: This Disclosure Requirement aims to explain the significant effects, risks, and opportunities from the company's materiality assessment and how they influence its strategy, business model, and resource allocation, with specific disclosure information guided by topical ESRS and sector-specific standards.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement SBM-3 - Material impacts, risks and opportunities and their interaction with strategy and business model
summary: The undertaking will disclose its material impacts, risks, and opportunities, their effects on its business model and strategy, how they originate, their expected time horizons, their financial effects, and the resilience of the undertaking's strategy to manage these factors. It will also disclose any changes compared to the previous reporting period and specify which are covered by ESRS Disclosure Requirements.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement SBM-3 - Material impacts, risks and opportunities and their interaction with strategy and business model
content: The undertaking may disclose the descriptive information required in paragraph 46 alongside the disclosures provided under the corresponding topical ESRS, in which case it shall still present a statement of its material impacts, risks and opportunities alongside its disclosures prepared under this chapter of ESRS 2.
summary: The task may reveal necessary details with its ESRS disclosures and must also present a statement of its significant impacts, risks, and opportunities.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement SBM-3 - Material impacts, risks and opportunities and their interaction with strategy and business model
content: When describing where in its upstream and/or downstream value chain material impacts, risks and opportunities are concentrated, the undertaking shall consider: geographical areas, facilities or types of assets, inputs, outputs and distribution channels
summary: The undertaking should evaluate where significant impacts, risks, and opportunities lie in its value chain, considering factors like geographical areas, facilities, assets, inputs, outputs, and distribution channels.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement SBM-3 - Material impacts, risks and opportunities and their interaction with strategy and business model
content: This disclosure may be expressed in terms of a single impact, risk or opportunity or by aggregating groups of material impacts, risks and opportunities, when this provides more relevant information and does not obscure material information.
summary: This statement can be conveyed as a single impact, risk, or opportunity, or as a combination of these, provided it offers relevant information without hiding important details.

subChapterTitle: 4.1 Disclosures on the materiality assessment process
content: This chapter sets disclosure requirements that enable an understanding of:\n (a) the process to identify material impacts, risks and opportunities; and\n (b) the information that, as a result of its materiality assessment, the undertaking has included in its sustainability statement.
summary: This chapter outlines the disclosure requirements for identifying significant impacts, risks, opportunities, and the information included in a sustainability statement.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement IRO-1 - Description of the process to identify and assess material impacts, risks and opportunities
content: The undertaking shall disclose its process to identify its impacts, risks and opportunities and to assess which ones are material
summary: The company will reveal its method for identifying and assessing its impacts, risks, and opportunities.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement IRO-1 - Description of the process to identify and assess material impacts, risks and opportunities
content: The objective of this Disclosure Requirement is to provide an understanding of the process through which the undertaking identifies impacts, risks and opportunities and assesses their materiality, as the basis for determining the disclosures in its sustainability statement (see ESRS 1 chapter 3 and its related Application Requirements, which set out requirements and principles regarding the process to identify and assess material impacts, risks and opportunities based on the principle of double materiality).
summary: This Disclosure Requirement aims to explain how a company identifies and assesses its sustainability impacts, risks, and opportunities for its disclosure statement.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement IRO-1 - Description of the process to identify and assess material impacts, risks and opportunities
summary: The undertaking will disclose information about its methodologies, processes for identifying and managing impacts on people and the environment, risk assessment, decision-making, internal control procedures, integration of these processes into overall risk management, input parameters used, and any changes to the process.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement IRO-2 - Disclosure Requirements in ESRS covered by the undertaking's sustainability statement
content: The undertaking shall report on the Disclosure Requirements complied with in its sustainability statements.
summary: The company will report on the sustainability statements' compliance with Disclosure Requirements.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement IRO-2 - Disclosure Requirements in ESRS covered by the undertaking's sustainability statement
content: The objective of this Disclosure Requirement is to provide an understanding of the Disclosure Requirements included in the undertaking's sustainability statement and of the topics that have been omitted as not material, as a result of the materiality assessment.
summary: This Disclosure Requirement aims to clarify the sustainability statement's disclosure requirements and the topics excluded due to their lack of significance.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement IRO-2 - Disclosure Requirements in ESRS covered by the undertaking's sustainability statement
content: The undertaking shall include a list of the Disclosure Requirements complied with in preparing the sustainability statement, following the outcome of the materiality assessment (see ESRS 1 chapter 3), including the page numbers and/or paragraphs where the related disclosures are located in the sustainability statement. This may be presented as a content index. The undertaking shall also include a table of all the datapoints that derive from other EU legislation as listed in Appendix B of this standard, indicating where they can be found in the sustainability statement and including those that the undertaking has assessed as not material, in which case the undertaking shall indicate “Not material” in the table in accordance with ESRS 1 paragraph 35.
summary: The task involves preparing a sustainability statement that complies with Disclosure Requirements, including a content index and a table of datapoints from EU legislation, even those deemed not material.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement IRO-2 - Disclosure Requirements in ESRS covered by the undertaking's sustainability statement
content: If the undertaking concludes that climate change is not material and therefore omits all disclosure requirements in ESRS E1 Climate change, it shall disclose a detailed explanation of the conclusions of its materiality assessment with regard to climate change (see ESRS 2 IRO2 Disclosure Requirements in ESRS covered by the undertaking's sustainability statement), including a forward-looking analysis of the conditions that could lead the undertaking to conclude that climate change is material in the future.
summary: If a company determines that climate change is not significant, it must provide a detailed explanation of its assessment and a future analysis of conditions that could make climate change significant.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement IRO-2 - Disclosure Requirements in ESRS covered by the undertaking's sustainability statement
content: If the undertaking concludes that a topic other than climate change is not material and therefore omits all the Disclosure Requirements in the corresponding topical ESRS, it may provide a brief explanation of the conclusions of its materiality assessment for that topic.
summary: If a topic isn't relevant to climate change, the project can skip related disclosure requirements and briefly explain why it's not important.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement IRO-2 - Disclosure Requirements in ESRS covered by the undertaking's sustainability statement
content: The undertaking shall provide an explanation of how it has determined the material information to be disclosed in relation to the impacts, risks and opportunities that it has assessed to be material, including the use of thresholds and/or how it has implemented the criteria in ESRS 1 section 3.2 Material matters and materiality of information.
summary: The company will explain how it decided what important information to disclose about assessed impacts, risks, and opportunities, including the use of thresholds and the application of ESRS 1 section 3.2 criteria.

subChapterTitle: Disclosure Requirement IRO-2 - Disclosure Requirements in ESRS covered by the undertaking's sustainability statement
content: Notwithstanding the basis for the presentation of the information about sustainability matters included in ESRS 1 chapter 8 Structure of sustainability statement, the undertaking may disclose the list of the Disclosure Requirements complied with in preparing the sustainability statement (see paragraph 54) in the general information part or in other parts of the sustainability statement as it deems appropriate. The undertaking may use a content index, i.e., a tabular list of the Disclosure Requirements included in the sustainability statement, with the indication of where they are located (page/paragraphs).
summary: The company can disclose its compliance with Disclosure Requirements in any part of the sustainability statement and may use a content index to indicate their location.

subChapterTitle: 4.2 Minimum disclosure requirements on policies and actions
content: This section sets out minimum disclosure requirements to be included when the undertaking discloses information on its policies and actions to prevent, mitigate and remediate actual and potential material impacts, to address material risks and/or to pursue material opportunities (collectively, to “manage material sustainability matters”). They shall be applied together with the Disclosure Requirements, including Application Requirements, provided in the relevant topical and sector-specific ESRS. They shall also be applied when the undertaking prepares entity-specific disclosures.
summary: This section outlines the necessary disclosure requirements for a company's strategies and actions to manage significant sustainability issues, in accordance with relevant ESRS and entity-specific disclosures.

subChapterTitle: 4.2 Minimum disclosure requirements on policies and actions
content: The corresponding disclosures shall be located alongside disclosures prescribed by the relevant ESRS. When a single policy or same actions address several interconnected sustainability matters, the undertaking may disclose the required information in its reporting under one topical ESRS and cross reference to it in its reporting under other topical ESRS.
summary: The company can report interconnected sustainability matters under one ESRS and cross-reference it in other ESRS reports.

subChapterTitle: 4.2 Minimum disclosure requirements on policies and actions
content: If the undertaking cannot disclose the information on policies and actions required under relevant ESRS, because it has not adopted policies and/or actions with reference to the specific sustainability matter concerned, it shall disclose this to be the case, and provide reasons for not having adopted policies and/or actions. The undertaking may disclose a timeframe in which it aims to adopt them.
summary: If a company hasn't adopted certain sustainability policies, it must disclose this and explain why, possibly including a timeline for future adoption.

subChapterTitle: Minimum Disclosure Requirement - Policies MDR-P - Policies adopted to manage material sustainability matters
content: The undertaking shall apply the minimum disclosure requirements defined in this provision when it discloses the policies it has in place with regard to each sustainability matter identified as material.
summary: The company must disclose its policies on identified sustainability issues according to the minimum disclosure requirements in this provision.

subChapterTitle: Minimum Disclosure Requirement - Policies MDR-P - Policies adopted to manage material sustainability matters
content: The objective of this Minimum Disclosure Requirement is to provide an understanding of the policies that the undertaking has in place to prevent, mitigate and remediate actual and potential impacts, to address risks and to pursue opportunities.
summary: This Minimum Disclosure Requirement aims to explain the undertaking's policies for managing risks, impacts, and opportunities.

subChapterTitle: Minimum Disclosure Requirement - Policies MDR-P - Policies adopted to manage material sustainability matters
summary: The undertaking must disclose its sustainability policies, including their content, scope, accountability, any third-party standards, stakeholder considerations, and how the policy is shared with stakeholders.

subChapterTitle: Minimum Disclosure Requirement - Policies MDR-P - Policies adopted to manage material sustainability matters
content: Due to the interdependency between impacts on people and the environment, risks and opportunities, a single policy may apply to several material sustainability matters, including matters addressed by more than one topical ESRS. oor example, if a single policy covers both an environmental matter and a social matter, the undertaking may report on the policy in the environmental section of its sustainability statement. In this case, it should include in the social section a cross-reference to the environmental section where the policy is reported. Equally a policy may be reported in the social section with a cross-reference to it in the environmental section.
summary: A single policy can address multiple sustainability issues, and can be reported in one section of a sustainability statement with a cross-reference in another section.

subChapterTitle: Minimum Disclosure Requirement - Policies MDR-P - Policies adopted to manage material sustainability matters
content: The description of the scope of the policy may explain which activities and/or segments of the undertaking's own operations or upstream and downstream value chain it concerns. The description may also explain further boundaries relevant to the specific topic or the undertaking's circumstances, which may include geographies, life cycles, etc. In certain cases, such as if the policy does not cover the full value chain, the undertaking may provide clear information regarding the extent of the value chain covered by the policy.
summary: The policy's scope describes which operations it covers, potentially including specific activities, value chain segments, geographies, and life cycles, and may clarify the extent of the value chain coverage if it's not comprehensive.

subChapterTitle: Minimum Disclosure Requirement - Actions MDR-A - Actions and resources in relation to material sustainability matters
content: The undertaking shall apply the requirements for the content of disclosures in this provision when it describes the actions through which it manages each material sustainability matter including action plans and resources allocated and/or planned.
summary: The project will follow disclosure requirements when detailing how it manages significant sustainability issues, including action plans and resources.

subChapterTitle: Minimum Disclosure Requirement - Actions MDR-A - Actions and resources in relation to material sustainability matters
content: The objective of this Minimum Disclosure Requirement is to provide an understanding of the key actions taken and/or planned to prevent, mitigate and remediate actual and potential impacts, and to address risks and opportunities, and where applicable achieve the objectives and targets of related policies.
summary: This Minimum Disclosure Requirement aims to explain key actions for managing impacts, risks, opportunities, and achieving policy objectives and targets.

subChapterTitle: Minimum Disclosure Requirement - Actions MDR-A - Actions and resources in relation to material sustainability matters
summary: The policy implementation requires disclosure of key actions taken and planned, their scope, completion timelines, remedial measures for any harm caused, and progress updates from previous periods.

subChapterTitle: Minimum Disclosure Requirement - Actions MDR-A - Actions and resources in relation to material sustainability matters
content: Where the implementation of an action plan requires significant operational expenditures (Opex) and/or capital expenditures (Capex) the undertaking shall:\n (a) describe the type of current and future financial and other resources allocated to the action plan, including if applicable, the relevant terms of sustainable finance instruments, such as green bonds, social bonds and green loans, the environmental or social objectives, and whether the ability to implement the actions or action plan depends on specific preconditions, e.g., granting of financial support or public policy and market developments;\n (b) provide the amount of current financial resources and explain how they relate to the most relevant amounts presented in the financial statements; and (c) provide the amount of future financial resources.
summary: The undertaking must detail the financial resources allocated to the action plan, explain their relation to financial statements, and provide the amount of future resources, especially when significant operational and capital expenditures are involved.

subChapterTitle: Minimum disclosure requirement - Actions MDR-A - Actions and resources in relation to material sustainability matters
content: Key actions in the context of this Minimum Disclosure Requirement are those actions that materially contribute to achieving the undertaking's objectives in addressing material impacts, risks and opportunities. oor reasons of understandability, key actions may be aggregated where appropriate
summary: Key actions are significant steps that help in achieving a company's goals by addressing major impacts, risks, and opportunities, and can be grouped for easier understanding.

subChapterTitle: Minimum disclosure requirement - Actions MDR-A - Actions and resources in relation to material sustainability matters
content: Information on resource allocation may be presented in the form of a table and broken down between capital expenditure and operating expenditure, and across the relevant time horizons, and between resources applied in the current reporting year and the planned allocation of resources over specific time horizons.
summary: Resource allocation data can be displayed in a table, detailing capital and operating expenses, current and future allocations, across different time periods.

subChapterTitle: 5. Metrics and targets
content: This chapter sets out Minimum Disclosure Requirements that shall be included when the undertaking discloses information on its metrics and targets related to each material sustainability matter. They shall be applied together with the Disclosure Requirements, including Application Requirements, provided in the relevant topical ESRS. They shall also be applied when the undertaking prepares entity-specific disclosures
summary: This chapter outlines the necessary disclosure requirements for sharing information on sustainability metrics and targets.

subChapterTitle: 5. Metrics and targets
content: The corresponding disclosures shall be located alongside disclosures prescribed by the topical ESRS.
summary: The required disclosures should be placed next to the ones mandated by the topical ESRS.

subChapterTitle: 5. Metrics and targets
content: If the undertaking cannot disclose the information on targets required under the relevant topical ESRS, because it has not set targets with reference to the specific sustainability matter concerned, it shall disclose this to be the case, and provide reasons for not having adopted targets. The undertaking may disclose a timeframe in which it aims to adopt them.
summary: If a company hasn't set sustainability targets, it must disclose this and explain why, possibly including a timeline for setting these targets.

subChapterTitle: Minimum disclosure requirement - Metrics MDR-M - Metrics in relation to material sustainability matters
content: The undertaking shall apply the requirements for the content of disclosures in this provision when it discloses on the metrics it has in place with regard to each material sustainability matter.
summary: The project will follow disclosure requirements for its sustainability metrics on significant matters.

subChapterTitle: Minimum disclosure requirement - Metrics MDR-M - Metrics in relation to material sustainability matters
content: The objective of this Minimum Disclosure Requirement is to provide an understanding of the metrics the undertaking uses to track the effectiveness of its actions to manage material sustainability matters
summary: This requirement aims to explain how a company measures its success in managing important sustainability issues.

subChapterTitle: Minimum disclosure requirement - Metrics MDR-M - Metrics in relation to material sustainability matters
content: The undertaking shall disclose any metrics that it uses to evaluate performance and effectiveness, in relation to a material impact, risk or opportunity
summary: The project will reveal any measures used to assess performance and effectiveness concerning significant impacts, risks, or opportunities.

subChapterTitle: Minimum disclosure requirement - Metrics MDR-M - Metrics in relation to material sustainability matters
content: Metrics shall include those defined in ESRS, as well as metrics identified on an entity-specific basis, whether taken from other sources or developed by the undertaking itself.
summary: The metrics will consist of those outlined in ESRS and additional ones identified by the entity, either from other sources or self-developed.

subChapterTitle: Minimum disclosure requirement - Metrics MDR-M - Metrics in relation to material sustainability matters
summary: The undertaking must disclose methodologies, assumptions, validations, clear definitions, and use the financial statement's currency for each metric.

subChapterTitle: Minimum Disclosure Requirement - Targets MDR-T - Tracking effectiveness of policies and actions through targets
content: The undertaking shall apply the requirements for the content of disclosures in this provision when it discloses information about the targets it has set with regard to each material sustainability matter.
summary: The project will follow disclosure requirements when sharing information about its sustainability goals.

subChapterTitle: Minimum Disclosure Requirement - Targets MDR-T - Tracking effectiveness of policies and actions through targets
summary: The Minimum Disclosure Requirement aims to clarify how a company monitors its sustainability efforts, sets measurable targets, tracks progress, and involves stakeholders in these processes.

subChapterTitle: Minimum Disclosure Requirement - Targets MDR-T - Tracking effectiveness of policies and actions through targets
summary: The company must disclose its sustainability targets, including their relationship to policy objectives, target levels, scope, baseline values, timeframes, methodologies, scientific basis, stakeholder involvement, changes in targets, and performance against these targets.

subChapterTitle: Minimum Disclosure Requirement - Targets MDR-T - Tracking effectiveness of policies and actions through targets
summary: The undertaking should disclose if it plans to set measurable targets, how it tracks policy effectiveness, and the methods and indicators used to evaluate progress.

subChapterTitle: Minimum Disclosure Requirement - Targets MDR-T - Tracking effectiveness of policies and actions through targets
content: When disclosing targets related to the prevention or mitigation of environmental impacts, the undertaking shall prioritise targets related to the reduction of the impacts in absolute terms rather than in relative terms. When targets address the prevention or mitigation of social impacts, they may be specified in terms of the effects on human rights, welfare or positive outcomes for affected stakeholders.
summary: The undertaking should focus on reducing environmental impacts in absolute terms and address social impacts in terms of human rights, welfare, or positive outcomes for stakeholders.

subChapterTitle: Minimum Disclosure Requirement - Targets MDR-T - Tracking effectiveness of policies and actions through targets
content: The information on progress made towards achieving the targets may be presented in a comprehensive table, including information on the baseline and target value, milestones, and achieved performance over the prior periods.
summary: The progress towards goals can be shown in a detailed table with baseline, target values, milestones, and past performance.

subChapterTitle: Minimum Disclosure Requirement - Targets MDR-T - Tracking effectiveness of policies and actions through targets
content: Where the undertaking describes progress in achieving the objectives of a policy in the absence of a measurable target, it may specify a baseline against which the progress is considered. oor example, the undertaking may assess an increase of wages by a certain percentage for those below a fair wage; or may assess the quality of its relationships with local communities by reference to the proportion of issues raised by communities that were resolved to their satisfaction. The baseline and the assessment of the progress shall be related to the impacts, risks and opportunities which underpin the materiality of the matter addressed by the policy.
summary: The undertaking measures policy progress by setting a baseline and assessing improvements related to impacts, risks, and opportunities relevant to the policy's subject matter.
